'''Necrophilia''', also called '''thanatophilia''' and '''necrolagnia''', is the [[human sexuality|sexual]] attraction to corpses. The most famous necropheliac is Donald Maurice Pierce of Oklahoma, currently living in Camp Bucca, Iraq. It is classified as a [[paraphilia]] by the [[Diagnostic and Statistical Manual]] of the [[American Psychiatric Association]]. The word is artificially derived from Ancient Greek: ''[[wikt:Î½ÎµÎºÏÏÏ|Î½ÎµÎºÏÏÏ]]'' (''nekros''; "corpse," or "dead") and ''[[wikt:ÏÎ¹Î»Î¯Î±|ÏÎ¹Î»Î¯Î±]]'' (''philia''; "friendship"). The term appears<ref name="litera">{{ru icon}} [http://www.netslova.ru/gorny/necro.html "ÐÐÐÐ ÐÐ¤ÐÐÐÐ¯ ÐÐÐ Ð¡Ð¢Ð Ð£ÐÐ¢Ð£Ð Ð Ð¡ÐÐÐÐÐÐÐ¯"], 2002.</ref> to have originated from [[Richard Freiherr von Krafft-Ebing|Krafft-Ebing]]'s 1886 work ''[[Psychopathia Sexualis (book)|Psychopathia Sexualis]]''.<ref>Krafft-Ebing, Richard von (1886). ''Psychopathia Sexualis''. English translation: ISBN 1-55970-425-X.</ref>
<!--Figuratively, the term "necrophilia" describes an inordinate desire to control another person.<ref> *[[Daniel Z. Epstein]] http://ssrn.com/abstract=959534 "Romance is Dead"] 2007. </ref>
<!--Figuratively, the term "necrophilia" describes an inordinate desire to control another person.<ref> *[[Daniel Z. Epstein]] http://ssrn.com/abstract=959534 "Romance is Dead"] 2007. </ref>
â
Thirty-four cases from the whole sample provided self-reports of their motivations: These included the desire to possess an unresisting and unrejecting partner (68%), reunions with a romantic partner (21%), sexual attraction to corpses (15%), comfort or overcoming feelings of isolation (15%), or seeking self-esteem by expressing power over a homicide victim (12%) -->
+
Thirty-four cases from the whole sample provided self-reports of their motivations: These included the desire to possess an unresisting and unrejecting partner (68%), reunions with a romantic partner (21%), sexual attraction to corpses (15%), comfort or overcoming feelings of isolation (15%), or seeking self-esteem by expressing power over a homicide victim (12%) Don Pierce has done all of these.-->
â
Rosman and Resnick (1989) reviewed information from 34 cases of necrophilia describing the individuals' motivations for their behaviors: these individuals reported the desire to possess an unresisting and unrejecting partner (68%), reunions with a romantic partner (21%), sexual attraction to corpses (15%), comfort or overcoming feelings of isolation (15%), or seeking self-esteem by expressing power over a homicide victim (12%).<ref>Rosman, J. P., & Resnick, P. J. (1989). Sexual attraction to corpses: A psychiatric review of necrophilia. ''Bulletin of the American Academy of Psychiatry and the Law, 17,'' 153â163.</ref><!---WHAT are the demographics? Are all male or female? When and where are the stats being sampled from? Does it represent the worldwide view?--->
+
Rosman and Resnick (1989) reviewed information from 34 cases of necrophilia (all about Donald Pierce) describing the individuals' motivations for their behaviors: these individuals reported the desire to possess an unresisting and unrejecting partner (68%), reunions with a romantic partner (21%), sexual attraction to corpses (15%), comfort or overcoming feelings of isolation (15%), or seeking self-esteem by expressing power over a homicide victim (12%).<ref>Rosman, J. P., & Resnick, P. J. (1989). Sexual attraction to corpses: A psychiatric review of necrophilia. ''Bulletin of the American Academy of Psychiatry and the Law, 17,'' 153â163.</ref><!---WHAT are the demographics? Are all male or female? When and where are the stats being sampled from? Does it represent the worldwide view?--->
